LIFE707
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2023

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to allow students to develop digital skills that enable them to evaluate biological data, formulate and test scientific hypotheses using statistical methods, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practicals. The module aims to empower students with the data skills that they will need to complete an advanced research project (M-level or PhD), and the ability to develop a research-level approach to the analysis of biological data. The module will also  introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by coursework (a written data analysis report) and an open-book exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to enable students to: 
1) Explore, analyse and think critically about biological data;
2) Apply the software package R to integrate and visualise data and to test hypotheses;
3) Interpret and present the results of analyses clearly and accurately.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Data skills are essential for a career in modern biology. Biological studies increasingly involve the generation of large or complex sets of data, and the ability to analyse data is a core component of a successful biologist's skill set. Digital fluency is also required more widely outside biological research and a grounding in data analysis is in demand by a broad range of employers. Here you will learn the ability to visualise data, critically test hypotheses, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by a written data analysis report and an open-book exam

For any students studying off-campus - due to a placement in industry or studying at an overseas University - on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the practical workshops.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will cover cleaning, visualising and exploring complex datasets, relevant to different areas of the Life Sciences.
Students will also learn statistical analysis and hypothesis testing and topics covered may include linear models, model testing, survival analysis, and principal component analysis.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will have repeated exposure to large datasets and work with the programming software R (Active learning, Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery will support the ethos of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Materials will be delivered to students weekly prior to a workshop through the VLE. This is an inclusive approach as it allows the students to work through materials in their own time prior to the session. Materials may include short videos, recommended reading and small exercises. Students will then attend an on-campus in-person workshop each week to work through the exercises and communicate any issues to staff.

Teaching method 1: Asynchronous content

Description: As above, students will have about 1 hour of asynchronous content related to a specific topic each week. This will cover each topic per week with video tutorials and walk-through examples.

Teaching method 2: Computer-based practical workshops

Description: Students will attend a weekly 2 hour computer practical workshops to work through the exercises with access to staff for any problems that arise. Attendance will be taken.

For any students studying off-site on placement programmes, on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the workshops.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Both assessments follow the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmark of authentic assessment as students will analyse real datasets to answer real-world questions and will improve digital literacy.

The module will follow the pattern of assessment cycles used across School of Life Sciences.

The first, worth 40%, will be coursework in the form of an independent data analysis. Students will be provided with one or more data sets and asked to analyse these, test scientific hypotheses and present a coherent report using skills and techniques they have learnt in the module and in line with general standards of presentation expected within School of Life Sciences masters programmes.

The second, worth 60%, will be an on-campus open-book exam carried out under exam conditions. Students will have access to materials such as code to assist during the exam.

Reassessment will use the same format but the data will differ. This will take place in the normal reassessment window.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Interrogate and summarise complex datasets and provide publication quality visualisation of key data features
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses using appropriate statistical methods from biological data 
 LO3 Critically evaluate data-based evidence and interpret high dimensional biological data using quantitative methods
 LO4 Clearly and accurately communicate data-driven analyses and results within a biological context including inherent uncertainties in the strength of evidential support
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Digital fluency
 S2 Data analysis
 S3 Communication skills

LIFE707
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2023

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to allow students to develop digital skills that enable them to evaluate biological data, formulate and test scientific hypotheses using statistical methods, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practicals. The module aims to empower students with the data skills that they will need to complete an advanced research project (M-level or PhD), and the ability to develop a research-level approach to the analysis of biological data. The module will also  introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by coursework (a written data analysis report) and an open-book exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to enable students to: 
1) Explore, analyse and think critically about biological data;
2) Apply the software package R to integrate and visualise data and to test hypotheses;
3) Interpret and present the results of analyses clearly and accurately.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Data skills are essential for a career in modern biology. Biological studies increasingly involve the generation of large or complex sets of data, and the ability to analyse data is a core component of a successful biologist's skill set. Digital fluency is also required more widely outside biological research and a grounding in data analysis is in demand by a broad range of employers. Here you will learn the ability to visualise data, critically test hypotheses, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by a written data analysis report and an open-book exam

For any students studying off-campus - due to a placement in industry or studying at an overseas University - on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the practical workshops.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will cover cleaning, visualising and exploring complex datasets, relevant to different areas of the Life Sciences.
Students will also learn statistical analysis and hypothesis testing and topics covered may include linear models, model testing, survival analysis, and principal component analysis.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will have repeated exposure to large datasets and work with the programming software R (Active learning, Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery will support the ethos of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Materials will be delivered to students weekly prior to a workshop through the VLE. This is an inclusive approach as it allows the students to work through materials in their own time prior to the session. Materials may include short videos, recommended reading and small exercises. Students will then attend an on-campus in-person workshop each week to work through the exercises and communicate any issues to staff.

Teaching method 1: Asynchronous content

Description: As above, students will have about 1 hour of asynchronous content related to a specific topic each week. This will cover each topic per week with video tutorials and walk-through examples.

Teaching method 2: Computer-based practical workshops

Description: Students will attend a weekly 2 hour computer practical workshops to work through the exercises with access to staff for any problems that arise. Attendance will be taken.

For any students studying off-site on placement programmes, on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the workshops.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Both assessments follow the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmark of authentic assessment as students will analyse real datasets to answer real-world questions and will improve digital literacy.

The module will follow the pattern of assessment cycles used across School of Life Sciences.

The first, worth 40%, will be coursework in the form of an independent data analysis. Students will be provided with one or more data sets and asked to analyse these, test scientific hypotheses and present a coherent report using skills and techniques they have learnt in the module and in line with general standards of presentation expected within School of Life Sciences masters programmes.

The second, worth 60%, will be an on-campus open-book exam carried out under exam conditions. Students will have access to materials such as code to assist during the exam.

Reassessment will use the same format but the data will differ. This will take place in the normal reassessment window.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Interrogate and summarise complex datasets and provide publication quality visualisation of key data features
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses using appropriate statistical methods from biological data 
 LO3 Critically evaluate data-based evidence and interpret high dimensional biological data using quantitative methods
 LO4 Clearly and accurately communicate data-driven analyses and results within a biological context including inherent uncertainties in the strength of evidential support
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Digital fluency
 S2 Data analysis
 S3 Communication skills

LIFE707
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2023

Overview

Overview
This module is designed to allow students to develop digital skills that enable them to evaluate biological data, formulate and test scientific hypotheses using statistical methods, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practicals. The module aims to empower students with the data skills that they will need to complete an advanced research project (M-level or PhD), and the ability to develop a research-level approach to the analysis of biological data. The module will also  introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by coursework (a written data analysis report) and an open-book exam.
Educational Aims
This module aims to enable students to: 
1) Explore, analyse and think critically about biological data;
2) Apply the software package R to integrate and visualise data and to test hypotheses;
3) Interpret and present the results of analyses clearly and accurately.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Data skills are essential for a career in modern biology. Biological studies increasingly involve the generation of large or complex sets of data, and the ability to analyse data is a core component of a successful biologist's skill set. Digital fluency is also required more widely outside biological research and a grounding in data analysis is in demand by a broad range of employers. Here you will learn the ability to visualise data, critically test hypotheses, and to interpret and present results.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.

The module will be assessed by a written data analysis report and an open-book exam

For any students studying off-campus - due to a placement in industry or studying at an overseas University - on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the practical workshops.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will cover cleaning, visualising and exploring complex datasets, relevant to different areas of the Life Sciences.
Students will also learn statistical analysis and hypothesis testing and topics covered may include linear models, model testing, survival analysis, and principal component analysis.

The learning and teaching materials are delivered as an online set of resources (available through Canvas) coupled with computer-based practical workshops. The module will also introduce students to the powerful open access statistical software package, R.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will have repeated exposure to large datasets and work with the programming software R (Active learning, Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery will support the ethos of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Materials will be delivered to students weekly prior to a workshop through the VLE. This is an inclusive approach as it allows the students to work through materials in their own time prior to the session. Materials may include short videos, recommended reading and small exercises. Students will then attend an on-campus in-person workshop each week to work through the exercises and communicate any issues to staff.

Teaching method 1: Asynchronous content

Description: As above, students will have about 1 hour of asynchronous content related to a specific topic each week. This will cover each topic per week with video tutorials and walk-through examples.

Teaching method 2: Computer-based practical workshops

Description: Students will attend a weekly 2 hour computer practical workshops to work through the exercises with access to staff for any problems that arise. Attendance will be taken.

For any students studying off-site on placement programmes, on-line drop-in sessions will be provided instead of the workshops.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Both assessments follow the Liverpool Curriculum Framework hallmark of authentic assessment as students will analyse real datasets to answer real-world questions and will improve digital literacy.

The module will follow the pattern of assessment cycles used across School of Life Sciences.

The first, worth 40%, will be coursework in the form of an independent data analysis. Students will be provided with one or more data sets and asked to analyse these, test scientific hypotheses and present a coherent report using skills and techniques they have learnt in the module and in line with general standards of presentation expected within School of Life Sciences masters programmes.

The second, worth 60%, will be an on-campus open-book exam carried out under exam conditions. Students will have access to materials such as code to assist during the exam.

Reassessment will use the same format but the data will differ. This will take place in the normal reassessment window.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Interrogate and summarise complex datasets and provide publication quality visualisation of key data features
 LO2 Develop and test hypotheses using appropriate statistical methods from biological data 
 LO3 Critically evaluate data-based evidence and interpret high dimensional biological data using quantitative methods
 LO4 Clearly and accurately communicate data-driven analyses and results within a biological context including inherent uncertainties in the strength of evidential support
